Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story: The phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was finishing up a routine check-in call with a new client. He sounded nervous, asking for some basic operating tips for the machine I’d just serviced. I could hear the uncertainty in his voice, and I knew how important it was to make sure he felt confident—my reputation depended on it. But as I glanced at the clock, I realized I was already late for the family video call. My daughter had reminded me twice this week: “Dad, it’s important for the kids to see you before the holiday. They miss you.” I could picture my grandchildren waiting, their faces lighting up when I joined. The client’s questions kept coming, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. I wanted to be the reliable expert, but I also wanted to be the present grandfather. My heart tugged in two directions, and for a moment, I just sat there, phone in hand, caught between the expectations of those who needed me.
